awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Universal skills for Geoscience Graduate Student Success in the Workforce
awd_abstract_narration:
Although geoscience professions have evolved with geoscience research and technology, different skills and competencies are needed by graduate students to be successful in the non-academic workforce. The investigators propose to determine the skills and competencies that should be part of graduate geoscience education, and the best means of developing these in graduate geoscience programs nationally. They will build on accomplishments from their previous initiative "The Future of Undergraduate Geoscience Education". This effort worked with geoscience employers and academics to identify skills, competencies and concepts needed by undergraduates to be successful in graduate school and the future workforce. Department heads and Chairs from across the country developed action plans for incorporating these results into their departments' undergraduate programs. 

For this activity, the investigators will hold an Employers Workshop with participants that span the breadth of geoscience professions to define the skills and competencies geoscience graduate students need to be successful in the workforce more broadly than academia. They will invite a range of employers from those actively involved in recruiting new hires to senior executives. Subsequently the investigators will organize a summit for departmental heads, chairs, and graduate program directors to discuss ways to implement change in individual departments and programs. Participants will be invited from a broad spectrum of earth, ocean, and atmospheric science programs at Masters and PhD granting institutions. An important outcome will be the transformation of graduate level curriculum for geoscience programs to better align course offerings and activities with future professional needs of earth, ocean and atmospheric sciences students.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

por.por_cntn:
This project brought together Department Chairs and graduate program directors, as well as faculty in the broader geosciences (earth, oceans and atmospheres), with a wide range of geoscience employers, professional society representatives and other stakeholders in graduate geoscience education to come to a consensus on the critical skills and competencies required by M.S. and Ph.D. geoscience graduates, and to see how current geoscience graduate programs are developing (or not) these skills and competencies in their graduate students.   Meetings included an initial Geoscience Employers Workshop, a Summit event for academic geoscience leaders, several years of Earth Educator Rendezvous workshops for geoscience Heads and Chairs, and a final series of mixed workshops engaging geoscience employers and academic geoscientists directly, along with a selected group of graduate students.  

While there was consensus that current graduate educational practices in the geosciences were providing students with a solid background in the technical and conceptual skills central to doing geoscience research, concerns were raised about the ability of M.S. and Ph.D. geoscience graduates to identify scientific problems, and about whether they were sufficiently abreast of the rapid changes in the scientific and professional science worlds being wrought by "big data" and the associated need for computational, coding, and data management and visualization skills.   As well, current graduates were seen as lacking in key professional skills, in particular the abililty to communicate science content to a range of non-technical audiences, and the ability to approach the addressing of scientific questions and issues from an entrepeneurial perspective.  Concerns were raised as to how adaptable and flexible current graduates might be with respect to an ever ever more rapidly changing geo-scientific world.  

Key recommendations include being much more intentional in graduate student advising, including the use of individual development plans as a foundation for student advising and mentoring; and to better leverage co-curricular resources from the private sector and from geoscience professional organizations toward providing graduates with more intensive professional development opportunities.  These recommendations are compiled in a new volume "Vision and Change in the Geosciences: Shaping the Future of Graduate Geoscience Education", which was published by the American Geosciences Institute in September of 2023, and distributed to geoscience graduate programs nationwide.
